Description: Terracotta figure of Osiris-Canopus. Osiris-in-a-jar, wearing the nemes headdress and a crown with ears of wheat, disc and plumes. A rectangular amulet lies on the ‘chest’, with uncertain details in relief above and below. A wreath encircles the base of the jar. A flat-fronted plinth with horizontal mouldings. Back plain; small circular vent. The feathers of the crown are lost and the underside of the plinth has been filed flat in modern times. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt, with traces on the front of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1889.1240, perhaps from Hawara; Breccia 1934: pl. xxxvii:182; Dunand 1990: nos 429 and 430, dated Roman period (430 = Guimet 1903: pl. III, from Gayet’s fabricated Tomb of Leukyoné at Antinoopolis); Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 45, right; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 59:1; Paul 1959: no. 291; Petrie Museum uc50516, from the Fayum. Near: Dunand 1979: no. 362 = LIMC vii (2): pl. 85, Osiris Kanopos 41; the very worn Török 1995: no. 112. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: 323, no. 785.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3026)
